Award.AwardTitle: EXP: GeoGames - online map games for teaching and learning through a real-world spatial perspective

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Cyberlearning: Transforming Education EXP project, the investigators are aiming to learn how to promote geo-spatial thinking skills and ability to use data gathered geo-spatially to solve complex problems. The technology being refined leverages on-line maps to situate scenarios in GeoGames so that learners have access to real GIS, remote sensing, socioeconomic, agricultural and other data and models as they engage with others to solve real-world problems in the GeoGame. The focus is on helping learners gain and use a spatial perspective in their thinking and problem solving. Geogames present real-world challenges that require large-scale data collected across geographical areas in game-like ways to draw in the learners; the learners solve problems using the data found through navigating the maps and in conjunction with each other. Research is carried out in the context of a particular GeoGame called Green Revolution. In that simulation, students take on the roles of rural farmers in a developing country and interact with each other to deal with water and weather issues. Learners navigate geo-spatial representations (world maps) to access real data that allow them to make predictions together and develop strategies together for making it through coming storms, pest infestations, and other real-world hazzards. Already learned in that project is that solving problems together in such a simulated real-world context promotes better understanding of the difficulties involved in the lives of farmers in developing countries and some of strategies that might lead to success. Research in this new project focus on trade-offs between complexity of the factors that might be considered in solving complex real-world problems and learning outcomes. The GeoGame technology and its use integrate the strengths of geo-spatial technologies, gaming, and social networking with availability of real-world data to promote learning about real-world facts and also complex, interlinked human, environmental, and technological systems in an experiential, collaborative, and engaging way. The focus is at the college level but ultimately could be appropriate for high-schoolers, middle-schoolers, and the general population.

Policy people tell us that a geo-spatial perspective is essential in addressing many of society's pressing issues (e.g., economics, agriculture, climate change, transportation, relief, urban planning, emergency services). This approach of GeoGames may provide an engaging and broadly-applicable way to educate future policy makers in taking a global perspective on both the global and local problems they address. The approach may also provide a way to help the public appreciate the connectedness of the world, the broad implications of local policy decisions, and the issues that must be considered in policy making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Schools and Universities around the U.S. are increasingly using computer based learning technologies to deliver their curricula. Computer based educational games and simulations are part of this trend, yet most of these software are not tested rigorously against anticipated learning outcomes. As a Cyberlearning project, we have not just sought to identify and develop a new learning technology configuration. We have also explored how learning happens within that particular genre so that we can generate testable hypotheses that can help other research and development efforts to build on our findings.

The technology configuration we have developed in this project is called GeoGames. This is a unique integration of state-of-the-art Geographic Information Systems and Online Multi-Player Game technologies. You may think of it as a board game that is played on top of the online, interactive maps that you find on the web, e.g. Google and Bing maps. What makes our GeoGame genre unique is the specific combination of four properties:

  1. Location – the space-time location of game entities, such as players, avatars, tokens or other game objects are important to the game dynamics.
  2. Spatial expansion – the game environment expands beyond a game board, a room, or a soccer field, to larger geographic spaces like villages, cities, countries and continents.
  3. Representation – the game digitally represents the real world as data on climate, soils, water resources, demography, economy, weather, traffic, and other geographic themes.
  4. Simulation – the game can provide feedback on user actions by simulating realistic behavior of the real world representations (change in water flow due to irrigation, decreased crop yield due to bad weather, et c.)

The GeoGame technology allows games to be played in different locations anywhere in the world, with different rules and scenarios, such that we can support anything from playing Monopoly on a street map of your home town, to a farming simulation in a small village in Punjab, India. This is made possible by using already existing geographic data resources produced by local, national and global data providers, and connect that data with existing scientific models that can simulate things like traffic flow, water runoff, population. We then present that system through a web browser as a game board so users can play together and experience a realistic and educational yet engaging simulation of some aspect of the world.

In our studies of this new technology we developed a farm game set in a rural part of India, and tested it in an undergraduate geography course at The Ohio State University as part of an assignment on food production in the developing world. These studies have verified that key learning goals are achieved, but that result on its own would not be very helpful to someone who wanted to develop another game using our technology, because they would not know what made the game helpful to the learner. So more importantly, we sought to identify some generalizable features that makes learning happen in this game.

Drawing on existing experiential learning theory, we hypothesized that short reflections during the game would affect students’ understanding of the farming activities. By separating students into slightly different versions of the game, where some were forced to answer short reflection prompts and others were simply playing through the game without those prompts, we were able to detect significant differences in their performance. We have also started to learn how we can analyze patterns of game play on the map as a way to measure how well students understand the rules of the game, which in itself is an expression of understanding the farming system in a very different part of the world.

Due to its exploratory nature of this grant, some of the findings so far are preliminary, but it is clear that we have developed a unique learning technology with the ability to provide a modifiable, interactive game board where our particular farming game is only one instance of an infinite number of games that can be developed on our platform. Consequently, it is also encouraging that our user testing indicate that there are some generic guidelines for how to make learning happen with this technology and how we can identify that learning.
